nodes.text: Firms may also raise capital by issuing preferred stock. Typically, holders of the preferred stock are promised a fixed dividend, which must be paid “in preference to” (i.e., before) any dividends can be paid to common stockholders.
If the preferred dividend is known and fixed, we can estimate the preferred stock’s cost of capital using

data.alt: Cost of Preferred Stock Capital equals StartFraction Preferred Dividend Over Preferred Stock Price EndFraction equals StartFraction italic Div Subscript italic pfd Baseline Over upper P Subscript italic pfd Baseline EndFraction

nodes.text: For example, assume AT&T’s preferred stock has a price of $25.43 and an annual dividend of $1.37. Its cost of preferred stock, therefore, is

data.alt: 1.37 divided by 25.43 equals 5.39 percent sign period
